text: [Music]
Um my name is Joseph. of a member of
parliament in Kenya and picture a Masai
village and one evening the government
soldiers come surround the village and
ask each elder to bring one boy to
school that's how I went to school
pretty much a government guy pointing a
gun and told my father you have to make
a choice so I walked very comfortably to
this uh missionary school that was run
by American missionary and the first
thing the American missionary gave me
was a candy I had never in my life ever
tasted candy so I said to myself with
all these hundred other boys this is
where I belong
stayed when everybody else was dropping
out. I'm you know my family moved. We
were nomads. Every time school closed
was a boarding school when I was seven.
You had to travel until you find them.
50 mi, 40 mi, it doesn't matter. You
slipped in the bush. But he kept going
and I stayed. I don't know why I stayed
but I stayed. And all of a sudden I
passed the national examination, found
myself in a very beautiful high school
in in Kenya. And I finished high school
and just walking and found a man who
gave me a full scholarship to the United
States. My mother still lives in a cow
hut. None of my brothers have gone to
school. And this man told me here go. So
I was I got a scholarship to St.
Lawrence University upstate New York.
Finished that. Uh and then after that I
went to Harvard school uh graduate
school finished that and then I worked
in DC a little bit. I wrote the book for
National Geographic and taught history,
US history. And every time I kept going
back home, listening to the problems of
these people, sick people, people with
no water, all this stuff. And every time
I go back to America, I kept thinking
about them. Then one day, an elder gave
me a story. And this story went like
this. Long time ago, there was a big um
big war between tribes. And there was
this specific tribe that was really
afraid of this larger tribe. And every
time they sent scouts out there to make
sure no one attacked them. So one day
the scouts came running and told the
villages the enemies are coming only
half an hour away they'll be here. So
people scrambled took their things and
ready to go move out and but there were
two men one man was blind one man had no
legs it was born like that. So the
villages the leader of the chief said no
sorry we can't take you you slow us down
we have to flee our children women and
children we have to run and they were
left behind waiting to die. But these
two people worked something out. The
blind man say, "Look, I'm a very strong
man, but I can't see." The man with no
legs says, "I can see as far as the end
of the world, but I can't save myself
from a cat or even an uh whatever
animals." So this man, the blind man,
went down on his knees down like this
and told the man with no legs to go over
his back and stood up. The man on top
can see, the blind man can walk. And
these guys took off, followed the foots
of the villagers until they found and
passed them.
So this this this was told to me in a
setup of elders and you know it's really
poor area. I represent northern Kenya
most nomadic remote areas you can even
find. And that man told me so here you
are. You've got a good education for
America. You have a good life in
America. What are you going to do for
us? We want you to be our eyes. We'll
give you the legs. We'll walk you. You
lead us. So the opportunity came as
always thinking about that. What can I
do to help my people? Every time you
know you go to an area where for 43
years of independence, we still don't
have basic health facilities. A man has
to be transported in a Wilberov to 20 30
km of hospital. No clean drinking water.
So I said, I'm going to dedicate myself.
I'm leaving America. I'm going to run
for office. So last July, I moved I
moved to America in June. Um ran in July
election and won. and and I I I came for
them and that's my goal. And right now I
have in place for the last 9
months a plan that in 5 years every
nomad will have clean drinking water.
We're building dispensaries across that
constituency. I'm asking my friends from
America to help with with being bring
nurses or doctors to help us out. I'm
trying to improve infrastructure.
I'm using the knowledge I received from
the United States and from my
community to move them forward. I'm
trying to develop homegrown solutions to
our issues because you know we realize
that people outside can come and help us
but if we don't help ourselves there's
nothing we can do. So my plan right now
is you as as I continue we introducing
students to different fields some become
doctors some lawyers. We want to produce
a comprehensive group of people,
students who can come back and help us
see a community grow that is in the
middle of a huge economic uh recession.
So, as I continue to be a member of
parliament and I as I continue listening
to all of you talking about boty,
talking about hell, talking about
democracy, talking about new inventions,
I'm hoping that one day in my own little
community which is 26,000 square
kilometers, maybe five times the size of
Rhode Island with no roads, would be
able to become a model to help others
develop. Thank you very much.
